3772.text: And again, with your economist hat, the labor market,

3775.text: you talked about the importance, not looking at the 6.5 percent threshold,

3780.text: A big debate-Steve Liesman's nemesis talks a lot

3783.text: about people being beamed to Mars.

3785.text: In your mind, what is happening in the job market?

3789.text: Is that why it's coming down

3790.text: or is it because people-the degree of discouraged workers?

3793.text: What is your sense of how quickly it's fallen because of new employment?

3801.text: So, on the first question, the chained CPI

3804.text: versus the fixed weight CPI is a technical issue.

3809.text: The chained CPI is technically better, according to most economists,

3812.text: because it allows for changes in the mix of goods

3816.text: and services that people actually consume more effectively.

3821.text: However, whether, you know, whether that's more appropriate for, say,

3827.text: Social Security indexing or not, I think that's ultimately a political decision.

3831.text: I suppose a rejoinder would be

3834.text: that neither the CPI nor the chained CPI may necessarily be a particularly good

3838.text: measure of the cost of living for Social Security recipients.

3842.text: So, those are the kinds of questions

3844.text: that Congress is going to have to deal with.

3850.text: Second part of your question was?

3854.text: The debate over the extent to which the unemployment rate is falling from-

3862.text: Yes. Well, you know, you can see the comparison by looking, for example,

3869.text: at the household survey, which gives estimates of how many people are added

3877.text: to the labor force, how many are added to the employed,

3880.text: how many people are leaving the labor force,

3882.text: and it's true that part of the decline in unemployment-and indeed all of it

3886.text: in the last reading, but over the recovery,

3890.text: part of the decline in unemployment has come from declines

3894.text: in participation rates, that is, people leaving the labor force.

3898.text: Some of that decline in participation appears to be due to longer-run factors,

3905.text: aging and changing patterns of work among women.

3910.text: So those things were probably not directly related

3917.text: But beyond that downward trend, there's been some additional decline

3920.text: in labor force participation, and in the ratio of employment to population,

3925.text: which presumably is linked to discouragement about the state of the labor force.

3932.text: So that certainly is part of the issue.

3935.text: That being said, obviously there has been a good bit of job creation.

3939.text: You can see that either in the household survey

3941.text: or in the payroll establishment survey.

3947.text: So I think there's no doubt that the labor market is considerably better today

3954.text: than it was two years ago, there's not any question about that.

3959.text: But it's also the case that many indicators

3962.text: of the labor market remain quite weak,

3966.text: ranging from the number of long-term unemployed to the number of people

3969.text: who have part-time work who would like full-time work.

3973.text: Wage growth obviously is very weak, and I could go on.

3982.text: So, it may be that the labor market is even a bit weaker

3988.text: than the current unemployment rate suggests,

3990.text: but I think that it is nevertheless the case that there has been improvement

3995.text: since the trough a couple of years ago.

4003.text: Mr. Chairman, Catherine Hollander from National Journal.

4006.text: How concerned are you that markets will have to tank in order to get lawmakers

4009.text: to reach a deal on the fiscal cliff,

4011.text: and what do you make of their recent complacency?

4014.text: Is there a Wall Street-Washington disconnect?

4019.text: Well, I certainly hope that markets won't have to tank.

4022.text: I don't-we want to have confidence, not just in markets but in businesses

4029.text: and households as well, and the best way the fiscal policymakers can achieve

4035.text: that is by coming to a solution as quickly as possible.

4045.text: Markets have obviously already responded to some extent, up and down;

4049.text: you can see from day to day how they respond to news about the negotiations.

4056.text: But on the other hand, it's also true, if you look at the experience,

4060.text: I think the very informative experience of the debt limit debate in August

4065.text: of 2011, that both confidence and markets remain pretty sanguine

4075.text: up to pretty close to the point where it looked

4078.text: like there was actually a chance the debt limit would not be raised.

4084.text: And then, of course, there was a pretty sharp shock, particularly to confidence,

4089.text: about the time of the, you know, of the final debates.

4098.text: So it's not unusual to see markets being complacent.

4105.text: Of course, there's from a market point of view,

4109.text: there are sort of risks in both directions.

4112.text: Obviously, things go badly, but perhaps if things go especially well,

4115.text: that would be good news, and maybe right now markets are sort

4118.text: of taking an average of those two possibilities.

4121.text: But again, just to reiterate, I don't think any policymaker, including the Fed,

4131.text: What we should be doing is making policy, you know, based on the fundamentals

4138.text: and doing what's best for the economy

4141.text: and I hope that fiscal policymakers will follow that injunction as well.

4154.text: Mr. Chairman, Steve Beckner of Market News International.

4158.text: With the federal government borrowing roughly $1 trillion a year

4162.text: and now with the Fed on pace to buy roughly a trillion dollars a year in bonds,

4171.text: are you concerned about a public, and possibly global,

4174.text: perception that the Fed is accommodating not just growth

4182.text: and are you concerned about what this might do to the Fed's credibility,

4186.text: and the credibility of U.S. finances in general,

4190.text: and the credibility of the dollar as the world's leading currency?

4195.text: Well, first of all, just a couple of facts.

4200.text: The-we're buying Treasuries and mortgage-backed securities,

4208.text: So we're buying considerably less than the Treasury is issuing and, moreover,

4215.text: the share of outstanding Treasuries that the Federal Reserve owns is not all

4218.text: that different from what it was before the crisis,

4221.text: because while our holdings have increased,

4223.text: so has the-obviously the stock of Treasuries in public hands.

4227.text: So it's not quite evident that there has been such a radical shift there.

4232.text: You know, we've been increasing our balance sheet now for some time,

4236.text: and we've been very clear that this is a temporary measure.

4241.text: It's a way to provide additional accommodation

4244.text: to an economy which needs support.

4247.text: We've been equally clear that we will normalize the balance sheet,

4250.text: that we will reduce the size of our holdings and-whether by letting them run off

4255.text: or by selling assets in the future.

4260.text: So this is, again, only a temporary step.

4262.text: It would be quite a different matter if we were buying these assets

4275.text: We are very clear about our intentions.

4278.text: And I think up until now, it seems our credibility has been quite good.

4285.text: There is not any sign either of current inflation

4288.text: or of any-there's no strong evidence that there are any increases

4293.text: in inflation expectations for that matter, looking at financial markets,

4296.text: looking at surveys, looking at economic forecasts, and so on.

4301.text: So, this is one of the things that we have to look at.

4304.text: Remember, I talked earlier about the potential costs of a large balance sheet.

4308.text: We want to be sure that there's no misunderstanding,

4312.text: that there's no effect on inflation expectations

4315.text: from the size of our balance sheet.

4316.text: That's one of the things we have to look at, but as to this point,

4322.text: there just really is no evidence that people are taking it that way.

4326.text: And I guess it's worth pointing out-of course we've been very focused

4329.text: on the United States here, but we're not the only central bank

4333.text: that has increased the size of its balance sheet.

4335.text: The Japanese, the Europeans, the British have all done the same,

4340.text: and very much more or less to the same extent in terms of the fraction of GDP,

4345.text: and I think the sophisticated market players and the public understand

4351.text: that this is part of a collective need,

4355.text: a need to provide additional accommodation to weak economies

4360.text: and not an accommodation of fiscal policy.

4370.text: Last but not least, Greg Robb, MarketWatch.

4373.text: There seems to be growing evidence that some of the MBS purchases,

4378.text: the impact of the MBS purchases, are that banks are holding on to some

4382.text: of the gains and not passing them on to the borrowers.

4386.text: Is there anything you can do about that and are you concerned about that?

4390.text: So the question is-just to restate your question-is about the spread

4396.text: between the mortgage rates that the public pays and the yields

4400.text: to mortgage-backed securities that banks may hold, and the question is,

4405.text: is that spread widening so that the full benefit of the reduction

4412.text: in MBS yields is not being passed through, that's the question.

4415.text: Well, I have to make sure everybody heard it, so you could answer.

4423.text: Our analysis suggests that it takes time-two points.

4431.text: The first point is that while we don't expect a hundred percent pass-through

4437.text: of MBS yields to mortgage rates,

4440.text: our empirical and theoretical analysis-and we've had quite a bit of work done

4446.text: on this issue-suggests that over time, the great majority of the decline

4451.text: in MBS yields does get passed through to mortgage rates.

4457.text: So we do anticipate, over time, that the full benefit will,

4464.text: or most of the benefit will, be seen by retail customers.

4468.text: And indeed, we have seen already a pretty significant decline

4471.text: since September in retail mortgage rates.

4474.text: But one thing that's perhaps confusing this issue a little bit is

4480.text: that there are other things happening in the economy

4484.text: So, for example, there are capacity limitations, which are allowing banks to,

4493.text: you know, to charge higher yields, there's extra costs like concerns

4502.text: So there's a number of things happening in the economy which will tend,

4506.text: all else equal, to raise that spread between mortgage rates

4510.text: and MBS yields, so that's unfortunate.

4514.text: What we can try to do there, of course, is to try to encourage good policy,

4519.text: for example, on putbacks, that will reduce the perceived risk

4523.text: and cost to the banks of making mortgage loans.

4528.text: But again, you know, I think most of those things, like g-fees, for example,

4534.text: are not really in our control, but, again, taking all those issues as constant,

4540.text: it does seem to be the case that, over a period of time, not immediately,

4544.text: but over a period of time, most of the declines in MBS yields do find their way

4548.text: through to mortgage customers and thereby strengthen the housing market.
